hypotheses: Hypothesis 1a: Bilingual students will, on average, have higher scores in English as a foreign language compared to the monolingual group once controlling for individual and familial background factors.

Hypothesis 1b: Bilingual students with weaker majority language proficiency will demonstrate no advantages and will lag behind their monolingual peers as well as their bilingual peers with strong majority language proficiency.

There is significant variety among bilingual groups in terms of English proficiency. Groups with language combinations featuring similar orthographic scripts (e.g., Polish-German and Turkish-German) will show better potential compared to combinations with different scripts (e.g., Arabic-German and Chinese-German).
claim.statement: The study investigates the effect of immigrant bilingualism on learning English as a foreign language, controlling for confounding background variables and examining the effect of proficiency in the instructional language at school.

data.source: Assessment of Reading and Mathematics Development Study (ELEMENT)
data.wave_or_subset: Data focuses on the sixth grade elementary school sample.
data.notes: Data were collected from a representative sample of students from a major European city, controlling proficiency and background variables.

method.description: The study analyzed secondary data from a representative sample of students to investigate the relationship between speaking a minority language at home and English language achievement. The analysis controlled for background, individual, and school characteristics.
steps: Identify bilingual groups based on the language spoken at home.
Conduct descriptive statistics comparisons between monolingual and bilingual groups.
Fit multiple regression models to analyze the effect of bilingualism on English language achievement.
Control for background variables including cognitive abilities, socio-economic status, and German proficiency.
method.independent_variables: Bilingual group membership, German proficiency, socio-economic status, cognitive abilities
method.control_variables: Age, gender, socio-economic status, parental education, cultural capital

results.summary: Immigrant bilingualism is positively associated with English language achievement when controlling for background characteristics. Bilingual students with strong instruction language proficiency have advantages in learning English as a foreign language.

numerical_results.p_value: statistically significant results reported, exact p-values not stated

metadata.original_paper_title: The effect of speaking a minority language at home on foreign language learning
